raw_response:
Here is the requested JSON output:

```json
{
  "questions": [
    {
      "rank": 1,
      "topic": "Margin drivers / shrink / damages / media network",
      "question": "How much of the 90-basis-point gross margin expansion in fiscal 2025 is directly attributable to shrink reduction, and what specific operational changes drove this improvement?",
      "why_it_matters": "Shrink has been a persistent headwind for Dollar General, and understanding the sustainability of recent improvements is critical for forecasting future margin performance.",
      "source": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/dollar-generals-shrink-improvement-drive-151700455.html"
    },
    {
      "rank": 2,
      "topic": "SG&A drivers",
      "question": "With SG&A expenses rising 11.1% in 2025, what portion of this increase is structural (e.g., labor investments) versus one-time (e.g., store closures, impairment charges), and how do you plan to moderate SG&A growth in 2026?",
      "why_it_matters": "SG&A is a key lever for operating margin expansion, and recent increases threaten to offset gross margin gains from shrink reduction.",
      "source": "https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/DG/dollar-general/selling-general-administrative-expenses"
    },
    {
      "rank": 3,

      "question": "What are the leading indicators you use to measure the success of your SKU rationalization program, and how do you balance SKU reduction with the risk of lost sales from out-of-stocks?",

    },
    {
      "rank": 4,
      "topic": "Store productivity",
      "question": "How are you measuring the ROI on the $150 million store labor investment, and what specific productivity metrics (e.g., sales per labor hour, customer satisfaction scores) have improved as a result?",
      "why_it_matters": "Labor is the largest SG&A line item, and Dollar General’s ability to demonstrate productivity gains will be key to justifying further investments.",
      "source": "https://markets.financialcontent.com/stocks/article/marketminute-2026-1-12-the-value-renaissance-dollar-general-surges-as-thrift-conscious-consumers-reshape-the-retail-landscape"
    },
    {
      "rank": 5,
      "topic": "Pricing / markdowns / competition",
      "question": "How are you adjusting your promotional markdown strategy in response to heavier-than-expected fall promotions, and what impact do you expect this to have on gross margins in Q4 2025?",
      "why_it_matters": "Markdowns are a major gross margin headwind, and Dollar General’s ability to manage promotions without eroding margins is critical in a competitive environment.",

    },
    {
      "rank": 6,
      "topic": "Digital / delivery",
      "question": "What are the unit economics of your delivery partnerships (e.g., DoorDash), and how do basket sizes and customer acquisition costs compare to in-store transactions?",

      "source": "https://www.pymnts.com/earnings/2025/ceo-says-dollar-general-is-second-inning-digital-journey"
    },

      "rank": 7,

      "question": "What percentage of your 2025 sales were driven by SNAP recipients, and how are you preparing for potential headwinds from further SNAP benefit reductions in 2026?",

    },

      "source": "https://www.digitalcommerce360.com/2025/06/06/dollar-general-ecommerce-sales-q1/"
    },
    {
      "rank": 9,

The most pressing issues (e.g., shrink, SG&A, SKU optimization) were ranked highest, while longer-term or less material topics (e.g., store productivity KPIs) were ranked lower.",
  "reasoning_steps": [
    "Step 1: Gathered source context from recent Dollar General earnings releases, investor presentations, SEC filings, and credible industry commentary to identify performance drivers and pain points.",
    "Step 2: Mapped findings to required topic areas, ensuring each question addressed a specific, actionable issue with clear financial or strategic implications.",
```

questions.topic: Margin drivers / shrink / damages / media network
questions.question: How much of the 90-basis-point gross margin expansion in fiscal 2025 is directly attributable to shrink reduction, and what specific operational changes drove this improvement?
questions.why_it_matters: Shrink has been a persistent headwind for Dollar General, and understanding the sustainability of recent improvements is critical for forecasting future margin performance.

questions.question: With SG&A expenses rising 11.1% in 2025, what portion of this increase is structural (e.g., labor investments) versus one-time (e.g., store closures, impairment charges), and how do you plan to moderate SG&A growth in 2026?
questions.why_it_matters: SG&A is a key lever for operating margin expansion, and recent increases threaten to offset gross margin gains from shrink reduction.

questions.question: What are the leading indicators you use to measure the success of your SKU rationalization program, and how do you balance SKU reduction with the risk of lost sales from out-of-stocks?
questions.why_it_matters: SKU rationalization is central to Dollar General’s ‘Back to Basics’ strategy, but over-aggressive cuts could alienate core customers.

questions.question: How are you measuring the ROI on the $150 million store labor investment, and what specific productivity metrics (e.g., sales per labor hour, customer satisfaction scores) have improved as a result?
questions.why_it_matters: Labor is the largest SG&A line item, and Dollar General’s ability to demonstrate productivity gains will be key to justifying further investments.

questions.question: How are you adjusting your promotional markdown strategy in response to heavier-than-expected fall promotions, and what impact do you expect this to have on gross margins in Q4 2025?
questions.why_it_matters: Markdowns are a major gross margin headwind, and Dollar General’s ability to manage promotions without eroding margins is critical in a competitive environment.

questions.question: What are the unit economics of your delivery partnerships (e.g., DoorDash), and how do basket sizes and customer acquisition costs compare to in-store transactions?
questions.why_it_matters: Delivery is a high-growth channel, but Dollar General must prove it can scale profitably without cannibalizing in-store sales.

questions.question: What percentage of your 2025 sales were driven by SNAP recipients, and how are you preparing for potential headwinds from further SNAP benefit reductions in 2026?
questions.why_it_matters: SNAP recipients are a core customer segment, and Dollar General’s exposure to this group makes it vulnerable to policy changes and economic downturns.

questions.topic: Margin drivers / shrink / damages / media network
questions.question: How do you plan to scale the DG Media Network while ensuring it does not alienate customers or distract from core retail operations?
questions.why_it_matters: Retail media is a high-margin growth opportunity, but Dollar General must balance monetization with customer experience to avoid backlash.

questions.question: How are you responding to Dollar Tree’s fixed-price strategy, and what specific tactics are you using to maintain your 3–4% price discount relative to mass retailers?
questions.why_it_matters: Price perception is critical in discount retail, and Dollar General must differentiate itself from competitors while protecting margins.

questions.question: What are the key performance indicators you use to evaluate store-level productivity, and how do you plan to improve these metrics in underperforming locations?
questions.why_it_matters: Store productivity is a leading indicator of long-term profitability, and Dollar General’s ability to turn around underperforming stores will determine its growth trajectory.

parsed_response.topic_coverage: All required topics are covered: margins/shrink, SG&A drivers, inventory/SKU, store productivity, pricing/markdowns/competition, digital/delivery, and low-income consumer/SNAP exposure.
parsed_response.methodology_notes: Questions were prioritized based on (1) materiality to Dollar General’s financial performance, (2) timeliness of recent developments, and (3) strategic importance to investors. The most pressing issues (e.g., shrink, SG&A, SKU optimization) were ranked highest, while longer-term or less material topics (e.g., store productivity KPIs) were ranked lower.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Gathered source context from recent Dollar General earnings releases, investor presentations, SEC filings, and credible industry commentary to identify performance drivers and pain points.
Step 2: Mapped findings to required topic areas, ensuring each question addressed a specific, actionable issue with clear financial or strategic implications.
Step 3: Prioritized questions by combining financial materiality, recent trends, and investor focus, ensuring the top-ranked questions probed root causes and executable levers.
